passages.text: A look at OTA advertising revenue potentialTraction for ad revenues across eCommerce and delivery marketplaces, as well as on Expedia, suggest a growing opportunity for OTA ad revenue. We think an OTA ad revenue ramp could be a significant 3- year EBITDA and sentiment driver for the OTA sector, capitalizing on increasing direct traffic to OTAs and following the path of other marketplaces. We estimate that ad revenue could grow to \(0.8\%\) of sector bookings by 2030, vs \(0.2\%\) estimated today (Exhibit 3), and contribute \(5\%\) of total sector 2030 revenues. We see Expedia as the biggest near- term beneficiary, with ads growth potential to contribute \(31\%\) of Street EBITDA growth in 2026 (assuming \(65\%\) ad margins), and maintain our Buy rating. We think Expedia's ad traction is likely growing interest among its competitors, with Booking increasing its ad platform investments in 2025. We also think and ad launch by Airbnb is more likely than not in the next 12 months given greater management focus on new revenue opportunities.

ADvantage: monetize data, all season revs., better marginsOTAs offer a variety of products (CPC auctions, commission overrides, programmatic advertising space sales, affiliate channels, and custom campaigns) which help them: 1) monetize scale and first- party data for highly targeted listings, 2) help OTAs and supplier partners generate revenues both during lean (with visibility boosters) and busy (competitive) travel periods, and 3) increase profitability with high advertising margins.

Expedia reported 2024 Ad revenue (ex- Trivago) of \(639mn (+32\%\) y/y), or \(0.6\%\) of GBV. We est. Ad revenue (ex- Trivago) could grow to \(1.5bn\) in 2030, representing \(1.0\%\) of total GBV. Assuming a \(65\%\) margin for ads, we estimate EBITDA contribution could increase from \(0.5bn\) in 2025 to \(1.0bn\) in 2030.

Booking.com offers sponsored listings (CPC based) for its site, but has historically focused on partner programs (commission based) vs Ad products. Booking has indicated that the company is increasing investment in its Ads platform this year. Ad revenues are not disclosed, but part of "Advertising and other revenues" including Kayak and OpenTable. We estimate total Ad revenue from sponsored listings of about \(100mn\) in 2024 (about \(0.1\%\) of GBV) and see an opportunity for ads to grow to \(1.8bn\) in 2030 (assuming \(0.7\%\) of GMV and \(65\%\) margins).

Airbnb has not introduced Ad products on its platform yet, but mgmt. has suggested a potential revenue opportunity. We think an ads launch is possible by 2026, with potential for Ad revenue of \(\) 77mn\(in 2026 (- 0.1\%\) of GBV), ramping to\) \ \(764mn\) by 2030 \((0.6\%)\) , possibly contributing \(\) 0.5bn\(in EBITDA.\)

Tripadvisor's ad revenue is facing headwinds from: 1) lower OTA marketing spend, 2) changes to Google's SEO with Al overviews, and 3) competition in paid marketing channels impacting platform traffic. We expect Brand Tripadvisor's ad revenues (Core segment) to decline \(4\%\) in 2025, and further ramp in OTA's ad revenue efforts could be a headwind, increasing the importance of Trip's experience bookings (Viator) business.

Equity United States
OTA: Online Travel Agency
CPA: Cost Per Action or Acquisition
CPM: Cost Per Mille (or Thousand Impressions)
GBV: Gross Bookings Value
GMV: Gross Merchandize Value
SEO: Search Engine Optimization
ROAS: Return on Ad Spend
ROI: Return on Investment

We see the rapid growth of ad revenues across eCommerce and delivery marketplaces as setting a positive precedent for OTA (online travel agencies) ad growth. We list below (Exhibit 1) a few Internet marketplaces, including Expedia, that generate Ad revenue. Data from 2024, and our estimates, suggests Ad revenue ranged from \(0.6\% - 7.2\%\) of gross bookings value (GBV) and \(3\% - 16\%\) of total revenue. Importantly, this revenue increases marketplace take rates, and has potential to significantly improve margins.
Exhibit 1: Ad Revenue generated as \(\%\) of Total Revenue and Bookings 2024 Ad revenue of some internet cos. suggests range of \(3\% - 16\%\) of their Revenue
Source: BofA Global Research estimates, company reports. \\*Amazon GMV is based on BofA estimates, revenue excludes AWS. BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH

We think eBay's ad revenue ramp provides a compelling example of the potential growing ad revenue contribution for marketplaces with take rates similar to OTAs. Ad revenues have grown at \(17\%\) CAGR over the last 7 years, well above eBay's GMV CAGR of \(- 2\%\) (2017- 2024). As a percent of Revenue, eBay's ad revenue grew from \(5\%\) in 2017 to \(18\%\) in 2025, and if we assume \(65\%\) margins on this revenue, ad revenues could be contributing \(45\%\) of eBay's 2025 profitability.
Exhibit 2: eBay's Ad revenue has ramped up to about \(2.5\%\) of GMV eBay's Ad revenue as a percent of its GBV and revenue
Source: BofA Global Research estimates, company report, Visible Alpha

Among OTAs, Expedia explicitly discloses its Ad revenue, which has grown considerably over the last few years to \(4.7\%\) of 2024 revenue ( \(0.6\%\) of '24 GBV) vs. \(2.2\%\) in 2021 ( \(0.3\%\) of '21 GBV). We believe ads are also increasingly contributing to EBITDA (or offsetting "merchandising" to drive bookings), and we estimate Ads could contribute about \(15\%\) of company EBIDA in 2025, and \(27\%\) of '25 EBITDA growth (we assume \(65\%\) margin from Ads).

The ads ramp in the OTAs sector does have some additional complications, including: 1) OTAs like Booking already have programs to elevate hotel rankings with their preferred partner program 2) professional property managers could better capitalize on advertising individuals, and 3) ads could detract from the quality of organic listing rankings, however, eBay's success with all types of sellers (large and small) suggests many of these issues could be mitigated.

Many OTAs now offer a full suite of ad or promotional products - including cost- per- click sponsored listings, display ads, automated bidding, visibility boosters for peak- period prominence, and affiliate partnerships. OTAs make their Ad products more useful
by harnessing first-party user data and offer highly targeted inventory to third-party advertisers.

- Expedia generated advertising revenue of \(639mn (ex-TVago) in 2024 (about 4.7% of total revenue and 0.6% of total bookings). Expedia Group Media Solutions offers a variety of advertising products to help travel brands and advertisers reach high value travelers. Given comparable traction for other marketplaces, we estimate Expedia Group's Ad revenue (ex-Trivago) could grow to\)1.5bn in 2030, contributing 8.1% of revenue and representing 1% of total GBV. We see Expedia as the biggest year-term ads ramp beneficiary, with Ads potential to contribute up to 31% of the \(280mn Street EBITDA growth estimate for 2026 (assuming 65% margin from Ads).

- Booking.com reported \(1.1bn in "advertising and other revenues" in 2024 (-4.5% of total revenue). However, much of this comes from services offered by subsidiaries - OpenTable and Kayak. We assume comparable "ad revenue" to be about 10% of "ad and other revenue" or about \)100mn (0.1% of GBV) in 2024. Using Expedia as reference for Ad revenue ramp, we assume Booking's Ad revenue could grow to contribute about 0.7% of 2030 GBV, representing total Ad revenue of \)1.8bn in 2030 (4.7% of our 2030 revenue est.). We note that the ads ramp for Booking could trail Expedia as Booking also benefits from some of its partner programs like Preferred Partner and Visibility Booster with higher commissions (or take-rates).

- Airbnb has not introduced Ad products or sponsored listings on its platform yet, but mgmt. has alluded to it being a considerable revenue opportunity. There is a risk that the inclusion of sponsored listings could potentially disadvantage individual hosts in favor of professional managers. However, with a competitive platform for guest attention, and ad technology to ensure a fair marketplace, we think sponsored listings can be successful on Airbnb. We think Airbnb could launch Ads in 2026, with potential revenue of 0.1% of 2026 GBV (about \$77mn). We have a base case estimate of Ad revenues ramping to 0.6% of 2030 GBV, which is about \$764mn in 2030 Ad revenues (or 4.2% of 2030 revenue est.). We estimate a \$0.5bn EBITDA contribution opportunity for Airbnb assuming business can ramp to 0.6% of bookings by 2030.

- Tripadvisor generated \$949mn in Brand Tripadvisor revenue in 2024 (down 8% y/y). The segment revenue mostly comes from hotel metasearch (CPC or CPA basis), display advertising (CPM basis), and subscription-based advertising (flat fee basis). Ad revenues have been declining on TripAdvisor due to: 1) lower OTA marketing budgets and OTAs promoting direct traffic/loyalty, 2) adverse changes to Google's SEO with AI overviews, and 3) increased competition in paid marketing channels. We expect Brand Tripadvisor's ad revenues (Core segment revenue) to decline 4% in 2025, and further ramp in OTA's ad revenue efforts could be a headwind, increasing the importance of Trip's experience bookings (Viator) business.

Exhibit 3: Our estimates for Ad revenue for the three big OTAs (EXPE, BkNG and ABNB) We estimate big 3 OTA total Ad revenue to contribute about \(0.8\%\) of total GBV by 2030 vs. estimated \(0.2\%\) in 2024

We think continued improvements in AI-driven ad targeting, combined with vast user data (which is getting enhanced by greater use of loyalty programs) and extensive global platform reach with help unlock the ad revenue opportunity. Products like visibility boosters help fill low-occupancy windows, while sponsored placements let suppliers compete during higher demand periods.

Exhibit 5: Booking.com site with the following listings: 1) Preferred Partner "thumbs up", 2) Preferred Partner along with a sponsored ad, and 3) Preferred Plus Partner Different ways of promoting listings on Booking.com
Source: Booking.com website

OTAs offer a PPC auction that lets suppliers bid for premium placement alongside or above organic search results. When a traveler clicks the listing, the advertiser pays the agreed CPC rate to the OTA platform.

- Booking Network Sponsored Ads on Booking.com, Agoda, Priceline, etc. helps properties set daily budgets and max CPC bids. The winners earn top slots market "Ad" in destination searches.- Expedia Group's TravelAds sponsored listings help accommodation partners bid to appear in high-visibility positions on allied brand sites.
Key benefits: Advertiser only pays for clicks (not impressions), and advertiser partners can set daily budgets, geographic targeting, and device filters to reach high-intent travelers.

OTAs sell unsold banner and native- feed slots within their own sites and apps via realtime bidding (RTB). Ads may include recommendations or traditional display banners. Targeting leverages first- party traveler data (search- history, past bookings, demographics) to serve relevant offers or up/cross- sell.
Examples include: a local tour operator's ad to someone who previously searched for that destination, or a travel insurance company places a banner ad on the OTA's booking confirmation page.

Off- site audience extensionUnsold inventory can be exposed to external demand- side platforms (like The Trade Desk), allowing advertisers to reach high- intent audiences across partner websites and apps. Instead of waiting for the traveler to return to the OTA, the ad "chases" them across the open web, increasing the odds of converting before they book elsewhere. This yields a premium CPC because the audience segment is sourced directly from OTA behavior. Example: Expedia's PassportAds

The OTA partners with third- party publishers (travel blogs, influencers, or other websites) to embed OTA search boxes, banners, or deep links. Partners earn a part of OTA's commission (generally \(2 - 5\%\) ) for each booking made through these affiliate links. This extends the reach of the OTA and creates an additional revenue stream.

Example, a travel blogger includes a link to the OTA on their website, and the OTA pays a commission to the blogger when a booking is made by users clicking that link. Partners also gain access to traveler's reservation details, account management and quarterly updates on travel trends.
These are exclusive, full- screen banners on an OTA's homepage for a fixed fee, typically reserved for large hotel chains, tourist boards or other major travel brands.
Sponsored placements or dedicated sends within OTA newsletters or transactional emails (example, "Featured Partner of the Week").

Some OTAs like Expedia operate in- house "media studios) to produce branded video series, interactive travel content, or destination spotlights that integrate sponsor messaging directly into the browsing experience.
While these placements are not part of ad revenues (or included in our ad revenue estimates), they generate incremental revenues for OTAs.

Incite- only tiers require to pay the OTAs a small incremental commission in return for a "Preferred" badge and persistent elevation in search rankings. These programs reward top- performing properties with higher visibility even outside of short- term promotions.

Booking.com Preferred Partner Program caters to the top \(- 30\%\) of the properties listed on the platform by booking score, guest ratings and price competitiveness. The members pay an extra \(- 3\%\) commission for a "Preferred Partner" badge and priority ranking.
- Booking.com Genius Partner Program is free for suppliers to join but required fixed discounts (10-20%) to loyalty members. It helps deliver higher page views and booking rates to partners.

A variant on CPC where partners pay higher commission rates or flat fees in exchange for guaranteed top ranking on specific dates. Best suited to fill last- minute vacancies or to capture demand around major events. Example: Booking.com's Visibility Booster

Al and emerging automation tools enable OTAs and advertisers to continuously refine who sees which ad, when, and in what format. New technology helps optimize budgets in real- time, spotting trends early, and matching relevant ads to the right kind of traveler. By leveraging predictive modeling, creativity tools, and different ad channels, advertisers benefit from increased return on ad spend (ROAS). Below are a few areas where Al and machine learning models have significantly upgraded the ad landscape:

- Al models ingest first-party signals (search history, booking patterns, time-on-site) to identify fine-grained in-market segments like last-minute leisure travelers, business-trip bookers, etc.- ML models can help predict a user's likelihood to click or convert on a given ad creative. Time-series models project when a traveler is most likely to book, enabling precisely timed ad delivery.

- Generative tools can help stitch headlines, ad copy and images on the fly 
- tailoring each banner or native ad to the traveler's interests, and past behavior.- Al can help create contextual and real-time adaptation of ad content to external data feeds (weather, local events, price-fluctuations, etc.).

- Instead of static cost targets, Al can help adjust bids in real-time, helping advertisers balance cost against predicted conversion value (deliver better ROAS).- Sometimes the advertisers may also be able to pre-emptively reserve ad slots at lower rates based on forecasting models (which anticipate times of high travel interest (like holidays, weekends, etc.).- Data-driven attributions feed back into media-mix models, guiding re-allocation of ad spend towards better ROAS channels.- Al-driven pacing algorithms continuously monitor spend vs. performance goals, smoothing out budget allocation across the day or month to avoid under or over spend.

Digital advertising- especially in high- volume data- rich industries like travel is subject to many regulations and stringent requirements for user data consent, transparency, and privacy. Failure to comply could lead to heavy fines, reputational damage, and removal of ad privileges on major platforms.
- With federated learning (decentralized machine learning) models can be trained while keeping data private and local, in compliance with laws like GDPR (EU General
Data Protection Regulation) and CCPA/CPRA (California Consumer Privacy Act & California Privacy Rights Act).

Ad growth is a key driver for Expedia EBITDA, but still less than \(1\%\) of total bookings. We estimate Ads can contribute up to \(31\%\) of Expedia's Street EBITDA growth estimate in 2026, though some of this revenue could be reinvested in merchandising. We expect Ad revenue growth to moderate from current levels, but still significantly outpace company's topline growth (LT est. of \(- 6\%\) ), thereby growing as a percent of revenue and bookings.

Expedia Group Media Solutions offers a variety of advertising products to help travel brands and advertisers reach travelers. These include TravelAds Sponsored Listings, a pay- per- click solution for increasing hotel visibility. Other options include Accelerator, a cost- per- stay solution for boosting visibility in search results, and Co- op campaigns, a collective advertising solution. Expedia also offers Display Advertising solutions to raise visibility and engage qualified travel shoppers.

At Expedia's Explore 2025 (partner conference, May'25), the company announced many new Solutions for Travel Advertisers. These include: 1) Tools to leverage Expedia's first- party data to target travelers on other sites via The Trade Desk. 2) Tools for ad content creation collaboration and new reach capabilities with Beautiful Destinations (50mn followers). 3) Enabling Destination Marketing Organizations (DMOs) to sponsor bonus OneKeyCash rewards for travelers. 4) Automating bidding on travel ads and adding predictive budget insights on the travel ads dashboard.

1. TravelAds Sponsored listings: a hotel-focused, pay-per-click solution that lets property partners bid for prime placement in search results to boost visibility and room bookings. The advertiser often sets a specific campaign goal, such as maximizing clicks, conversions, or return on ad spend (ROAS). The automated bidding system analyses various factors, including historical campaign user data, user behavior, contextual signals (device, location, time), and competitive landscape. Based on the analysis, algorithms dynamically adjust bids in real-time to maximize the chances of achieving the defined goals while staying within budget constraints. The system continuously learns from campaign performance data and refines its bidding strategy over time to improve results. 
2. Flights Sponsored listings: a similar CPC auction for airlines to appear in top-flight search positions across Expedia group brands.

1. Display and Native advertising: Digital banners, interstitials, and native ad solutions to seamless integrate with the traveler shopping experience, often sued to highlight promotions and package deals. 
2. Accelerator: a cost-per-stay model where partners pay only when a booking occurs - ideal for budget-conscious visibility gains, with easy budget controls in Partner Central 
3. Co-op campaigns: Collective buys that let destinations, hotels, airlines and other travel brands pool resources for amplified reach and cost efficiency. 
4. PassportAds (Audience Extension): an off-site, behavioral-targeting solution that places ads across the open web - reaching travelers wherever they browse, based on Expedia's first party data.

Affiliate ProgramThe Expedia affiliate program lets website owners, bloggers, and other online publishers earn commissions by driving bookings through Expedia's platform. Partners can earn up to 4% commission (4% for hotels & experiences, 2% for vacation rentals) for every qualifying booking made through their site, link or widget within a 7- day window (post visitor click).

Creative and content services1. Media Studio: an in-house creative agency crafting immersive videos and interactive experiences (e.g. GoUSA TV series) that lets travelers "shop while they watch".2. Travel Spotlights: in-house agency helps create custom landing-page experiences for partners that showcase themed collection of properties or destinations.

Data, targeting, and insights1. Targeting: precise audience segments (in- market, last- minute bookers, luxury, family, business, etc.) powered by Expedia's first- party data.2. Real- time reporting and optimization: dashboards to deliver live metrics - impressions, clicks, booking lift, viewability - and AI- driven bid recommendations to maximize ROI3. Research and custom insights: proprietary ebooks, trend reports, and bespoke data analysis to inform strategy and validate campaign performance.

Recent ad- revenue trendsExpedia's Ad revenue as a \(\%\) of revenue has grown over the last few years, and ad revenues (ex- Trivago) were up \(20\%\) in 2Q. Expedia's 2Q Ad revenue of \(182mm\) was about \(5\%\) of its total revenue of \(3.8bn\) and about \(0.6\%\) of its total gross bookings value of \(30.4bn\) . This compares to 2Q22 Ad revenue of \(59mm\) , which was about \(2\%\) of total revenue and \(0.2\%\) of bookings value.

Exhibit 6: Expedia's Ad revenue contribution to overall revenue has grown over the last few years from about \(2\%\) in 2022 to \(5\%\) in 2024. Expedia's Ad revenue and Ad revenue as a \(\%\) of total revenue

Booking indicated that the company is investing in its Ad solutions this year (part of the company's \(\) 170\(mn growth investments). While the company hasn't disclosed its specific investments, we would expect improving ad platform targeting capabilities for its suppliers. We estimate that current Ad revenues contribute a very modest \(0.1\%\) of Booking's GBV. We see an opportunity for Ad revenue to grow to about \(0.7\%\) of GBV by 2030 based on Expedia's traction, though we note that Booking could rely more on commission boosters than its peers.

A cost- per- click (CPC) auction that spans Booking.com, Priceline, and Agoda. Properties set daily budgets and maximum CPC bids, and winning bids secure prime "Ad"- labeled placements in destination search results. Winning auction bids increases visibility among high- intent travelers.

According to Booking, \(250\%\) more clicks are generated by properties featured on the first page of their search results, and \(80\%\) of bookings are received by properties that appear on the first page.

A short term ranking override that temporarily elevates properties to top of search results for selected dates. Instead of a flat CPC, partners agree to a higher commission rate for those select dates in exchange for prime placement. It is ideal for filling last- minute cancellations or boosting occupancy around- high demand events. These revenues are included as part of transaction revenues.

It caters to the top - \(30\%\) of the properties listed on the platform by booking score, guest ratings and price competitiveness. The members pay an extra - \(3\%\) commission for a Preferred Partner "thumbs- up" badge and priority ranking in search results. Member status is reviewed every 90 days to ensure continued compliance with quality criteria. This helps partners increase trust and click- through rates even outside promotional windows.

Booking also offers Preferred Plus, which is the premium tier of their Preferred Partner Program, only available to the top \(10\%\) of Preferred Partners. It is designed as a visibility booster to help partners stand out from the competition and grow bookings.
This program is free for suppliers to join but required fixed discounts (10- 20%) to loyalty members. It helps deliver higher page views and booking rates to partners.

Through their affiliate networks (CJ in EMEA and Awin in RoW), Booking.com helps partners earn commissions by enabling partner's audience to book stays, transport, and attractions on Booking.com's platform. According to the Awin website, Booking.com's partners receive a \(4\%\) commission on all accommodations worldwide upon stay completion. Partners also gain access to traveler's reservation details, account management and quarterly updates on travel trends.

Booking.com sells remnant banner and native- ad inventory via real- time bidding on external demand- side platforms (DSPs). On- site "You might like" cards and display banners are served based on user behavior.

Booking benefits from advertising and promotional products in two ways: 1) Direct Ad revenue (reported as part of the "Ad and other revenue"), and 2) boost to take- rate from Preferred partner and Visibility Booster programs. In this report we focus on ad revenues (vs take rate programs).

Booking reported "Advertising and other revenues" of \(1.07bn\) in 2024 (4.5% of total revenue and \(0.6\%\) of GBV). However, most of this revenue was generated by Kayak and OpenTable, we assume only \(10\%\) of this is Booking's Ad revenue (about \(107mn\) ). This Ad revenue estimate would represent \(0.5\%\) of 2024 Revenue and \(0.1\%\) of GBV.

Assuming greater investment in and management focus on Booking's ad platform, and using Expedia's revenue ramp as a guide, our scenario below has Booking's Ad revenue growing to \(0.7\%\) of this GBV buy 2030, representing \(1.8bn\) of revenue in 2030 (4.7% of our 2030 revenue est.).

Airbnb still to comeAirbnb offers unique inventory and high number of hosts (5mn) that are competing for bookings, setting the stage for a profitable advertising model (eBay an interesting comp). However, there is risk that individual hosts are disadvantaged vs. professionals, who could have more sophisticated ad campaigns. Therefore, Airbnb management has suggested a measured rollout that may require extensive testing.

Given traction at other marketplaces and at Expedia, and management's increasing focus on growth opportunities, we think sponsored listings could be launched on the platform by 2026. We have a base case estimate for about \(\) 764\(mn in incremental revenues by 2030 (0.6% of GBV or about 4% of revenue). We estimate a\) \ \(0.5bn\) EBITDA opportunity by Ads by 2030 for Airbnb assuming the Ad business can ramp.

Airbnb CEO Brian Chesky has publicly discussed the sponsored listing opportunity several times, suggesting a material revenue opportunity, but also that the company will need to be thoughtful in its approach. For background, Airbnb's platform has over 5mn hosts with 8mn listings, and roughly \(10\%\) of hosts are professional property managers, which manage roughly \(33\%\) of all listings. Professionals are likely to be early adopters of sponsored listings, and could crowd out smaller and unique property hosts. Therefore, the company will likely need to develop an ad platform that ensures ease of use and possibly preferred placement for individual hosts.
Airbnb's current search ranking algorithm factors in:

1. The listing's total price before taxes, quality and reviews, and popularity (amenities, unique characteristics, high quality photos) affect how it shows up in guests' search results.  
2. The listing's availability, host response time to enquiries and reservation acceptance rate. Superhosts are also considered favorably.

We assume Airbnb launches Sponsored listings on its platform in 2026. Given need to testing to avoid marketplace disruption, we assume a measured annual ramp though 2030. Using other marketplaces as a comp, we see an opportunity for Airbnb ad revenues to grow to \(0.6\%\) of GBV by 2030. We highlight a range of what we think are reasonable potential outcomes for sponsored listings revenues as a percent of gross bookings below.

Assuming Airbnb can grow sponsored listings to \(0.6\%\) of its gross bookings (GBV) by 2030, the company could increase total revenues by about \(4.2\%\) and add \(0.5bn\) in EBITDA assuming \(65\%\) margins.

Tripadvisor's advertising clients are predominantly direct suppliers of hotels, airlines and cruises, as well as destination marketing organizations ("DMOs"), OTAs, and other travel related businesses. Tripadvisor's two most significant travel partners, Expedia and Booking (and their subsidiaries), accounted for a combined \(22\%\) of total revenue in 2024 (vs. \(25\%\) in 2023 and \(31\%\) in 2022), with most of this revenue recorded within the Brand Tripadvisor segment.

Brand Tripadvisor or Core revenue (about \(80\%\) is likely advertising revenue) has faced headwinds over the last couple of years, mostly due to: 1) OTAs/travel partners pushing for direct traffic/loyalty and curtailing advertising on Tripadvisor platform, 2) pressure on SEO traffic acquisition performance with search engines (primarily Google) changing their search result placement and underlying algorithms (like with AI overviews), and 3) increased competition in paid online marketing channels.

Tripadvisor-branded Hotels Revenue: The largest source of Brand Tripadvisor segment revenue is generated from click- based advertising on their hotel meta platform (also referred to as their hotel auction), which consists primarily of contextually relevant

booking links to partner websites (mostly OTAs and hotels). Click- based advertising is generally priced on a cost- per- click ("CPC") basis. CPC rates are determined in a dynamic, competitive auction bidding process. Tripadvisor also generates click- based advertising revenue on a cost- per- acquisition ("CPA") basis, with payments from partners determined by a contractual commission rate based on a traveler click generated on their platform that ultimately results in a hotel booking and stay via the partners' websites.

Tripadvisor provides additional business- to- business ("B2B") offerings to hotels and related accommodation partners. These include a subscription- based advertising solution, with revenue determined by a contractual fee and time duration, or other CPC- based advertising solutions through hotel sponsored placements on the platform.

Media and Advertising Revenue: Tripadvisor also offers advertisers opportunities to promote their brands through display- based advertising (or "media advertising") placements across their brands on the platform. Display- based advertising placements are predominantly sold on a cost per thousand impressions ("CPM") basis.

Tripadvisor Experiences and Dining Revenue: Tripadvisor platform merchandises experiences available on Viator and dining reservations available on TheFork and earns affiliate marketing commission revenue on bookings (made on Tripadvisor platform but fulfilled by Viator and TheFork, respectively). These transactions generate intercompany (intersegment) revenue which is eliminated on a consolidated basis.

Other Revenue: This includes Tripadvisor cruise, flight, and rental cars offerings generate revenue primarily through click- based and display- based advertising solutions. The vacation rentals platform displays and promotes vacation rentals inventory, including booking links to third- party booking partners, in exchange for a commission when travelers complete a booking on the third- party booking partner's website.
Tripadvisor Ad Express (formerly Tripadvisor Media Manager)

A self- serve ad platform that lets brands of any size launch, manage, and optimize campaigns quickly. They can choose from different ad formats like display banners, native in- feed units, or video ads and set precise targeting (by location, device, retargeting), and monitor budget and track performance on real- time dashboards.

This is a cost- per- click product where accommodation partners bid for "Sponsored" slots at the top of Tripadvisor's search results, on high- profile shopping pages, in the maps search and local competitor pages.
Hotels can plug their booking engine into TripConnect to show real- time rates directly into their listing page. TripConnect offers two products that help drive direct bookings:

- CPC model: Helps partners showcase direct rates and availability — and travelers can click through to partner website. Travelers arrive at partner booking page, to make bookings directly. Partners pay per click on the Tripadvisor link.- Instant Booking: it allows travelers to book with partners immediately on Tripadvisor. It is a "Pay for Stays" commission model that does not require up-front investment or a long-term commitment.

External publishers- travel blogs, metasearch sites, and influencers can join for free, embed Tripadvisor widgets or deep links, and earn commissions (typically 3- 4% of booking value) on any stays booked through their content. Affiliate marketing commissions are reported as a marketing expense by Tripadvisor.

Recent ad- revenue results and growthBrand Tripadvisor generated \(\) 949\mathrm{mn}$ in revenue in 2024, which was down \(8\%\) y/y, and represented \(48\%\) of total revenue (vs \(91\%\) in 2015). For 2025, mgmt. expects an improvement y/y to low single- digit revenue declines and a return to growth in 2026. However, this is mostly due to expectations from improved hotel commerce (in- app hotel bookings on Tripadvisor app) and experience & dining revenue, and not a material improvement in ad dynamics.

On- site ad volumes on Tripadvisor are seeing increased pressure, and we think these metasearch headwinds will continue. As the experiences and dining subsidiaries (Viator and TheFork) grow faster, we expect Brand Tripadvisor's share of total revenue to fall below \(40\%\) by 2027. We are constructive on growth in online experiences and continue to see Viator as the key Tripadvisor revenue and margin growth driver. Maintain our Neutral rating on the stock.

Our \(\) 146\(price objective is based on 17x 2026E EBITDA (representing 15.5x 2026 FCF). This multiple is at the higher end of our Marketplace comp group range reflects strong direct traffic, alternative accommodation category leadership, new growth opportunities, and significantly higher margins and FCF generation than marketplace peers.

Risks are: 1) multiple compression given high relative valuation, 2) potential for increased competition for incremental bookings driving up marketing spend, 3) decelerating room night growth from higher penetration, and 4) regulatory limitations on market growth.

Our price objective is \(\) 5,850\(based on 23x our 2026E EPS + Cash, which compares to Booking's 10 - year historical range of 10 - 24x. We think a forward P/E multiple premium to OTA peers is appropriate given higher quality of earnings, market share growth and strong FCF generation.

Risks to our PO are: 1) a global economic downturn or Global conflicts that reduce travel activity, 2) competition for traffic from Google lowering growth or margins, 3) hotels favoring their own distribution channels, 4) FX volatility, and 5) increased competition from Airbnb, Expedia, and Trip.com. The stock has been subject to heavy volatility in the past based on travel disruptions and this volatility could increase given global conflicts.

Our \(\) 240\(PO is based on a 50 - 50 blend of P/E and sum - of - the - parts valuations based on 2026 estimates. Our EV/EBITDA valuation is based on a 9x EBITDA, and our P/E valuation is based on 18x GAAP EPS. Our P/E multiple is within Expedia's historical ranges of forward EPS and a discount compared to Booking valuation given market share trends.

Downside risks to our PO are: 1) economic downturn or prolonged macro headwinds leading to fewer travel bookings, 2) competition for traffic lowering the company's growth or margin opportunity, 3) more aggressive direct booking initiatives by hotels, 4) Google traffic disintermediation, and 5) ongoing slowdown in VRBO growth post- pandemic.

Our price objective of \(\) 19\(is based on SOTP valuation with Core multiple of 5x on our 2026 est. EBITDA (lower end of OTA range of 5x - 18x, given Core's underperformance to OTAs). We value Viator at 1x and the Fork at 1x our 2026E sales, given high growth but low margins.
Downside risks to our price objective are 1) macro- economic and political factors

impacting the travel industry, 2) slowing growth and lower take- rates at Viator due to increasing competition in Experiences (e.g., Google, Airbnb, etc.), 3) challenges to the credibility of online reviews with more bots/fakes, 4) increasing marketing spend pressuring margins.

Upside risks to our price objective are 1) Viator gaining online share, 2) Potential sale of Viator, 3) improved margins with reduced marketing spend and more direct traffic, 4) pick- up in Tripadvisor- branded hotel segment monetization or in- app bookings, 5) reduced macro uncertainty and improved travel trends.

FUNDAMENTAL EQUITY OPINION KEY: Opinions include a Volatility Risk Rating, an Investment Rating and an Income Rating. VOLATILITY RISK RATINGS, indicators of potential price fluctuation, are: A - Low, B - Medium and C - High. INVESTMENT RATINGS reflect the analyst's assessment of both a stock's absolute total return potential as well as its attractiveness for investment relative to other stocks within its Coverage Cluster (defined below). Our investment ratings are: 1 - Buy stocks are expected to have a total return of at least \(10\%\) and are the most attractive stocks in the coverage cluster; 2 - Neutral stocks are expected to remain flat or increase in value and are less attractive than Buy rated stocks and 3 - Underperform stocks are the least attractive stocks in a coverage cluster. An investment rating of 6 (No Rating) indicates that a stock is no longer trading on the basis of fundamentals. Analysts assign investment ratings considering, among other things, the 0- 12 month total return expectation for a stock and the firm's guidelines for ratings dispersions (shown in the table below). The current price objective for a stock should be referenced to better understand the total return expectation at any given time. The price objective reflects the analyst's view of the potential price appreciation (depreciation).
Investment ratingTotal return expectation (within 12-month period of date of initial rating)Ratings dispersion guidelines for coverage clusterR2Buy≥ 10%≤ 70%Neutral≥ 0%≤ 30%UnderperformN/A≥ 20%
R2Ratings dispersions may vary from time to time where BofA Global Research believes it better reflects the investment prospects of stocks in a Coverage Cluster.

INCOME RATINGS, indicators of potential cash dividends, are: 7 - same/higher (dividend considered to be secure), 8 - same/lower (dividend not considered to be secure) and 9 - pays no cash dividend. Coverage Cluster is comprised of stocks covered by a single analyst or two or more analysts sharing a common industry, sector, region or other classification(s). A stock's coverage cluster is included in the most recent BofA Global Research report referencing the stock.
